title: 103_s1249
content: The Act may be cited as the "Tuberculosis Prevention and Control Amendments of 1993". Between 10,000,000 and 15,000,000 people in the United States have been infected with tuberculosis, with nearly 26,000 new cases reported annually and over 1,700 deaths each year. The number of reported cases has increased from 22,201 in 1985 to 26,673 in 1992. Additionally, drug-resistant tuberculosis strains can be costly to treat and have a high mortality rate. In 1992, tuberculosis cases were reported in all 50 states, with drug-resistant cases reported in at least 36 states, the District of Columbia, and Puerto Rico. In 1992, tuberculosis cases were reported in all 50 states, with drug-resistant cases reported in at least 36 states, the District of Columbia, and Puerto Rico. 27 percent of the reported cases occurred in foreign-born persons. One third of the world's population harbors tuberculosis, making it the number one killer among infectious diseases with 8,000,000 new cases and 2,900,000 deaths annually. SEC. 3. PROGRAMS OF CENTERS FOR DISEASE CONTROL AND PREVENTION. The amendment to the Public Health Service Act allocates funding for tuberculosis prevention, control, and elimination services. States applying for grants must submit a plan showing how funds will be used to provide services to high-risk populations or areas with high infection rates. The plans should also outline collaboration with funded entities. The amendment to the Public Health Service Act requires states to submit plans for tuberculosis prevention services targeting high-risk populations or areas with high infection rates. Plans must also demonstrate collaboration with funded entities and the use of grant funds for effective interventions. The Public Health Service Act is amended to support grants for tuberculosis research and training, with authorized appropriations for fiscal years 1994-1997. Technical amendments are also made to Section 317(j)(2) of the Act. The Public Health Service Act is amended to authorize appropriations for tuberculosis research and training until 1997. A technical amendment is made to Section 317(j)(2) of the Act. The Public Health Service Act is amended to authorize appropriations for tuberculosis research and training until 1997, including research and research training through the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases. The Public Health Service Act authorizes appropriations for tuberculosis research and training through the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases until 1997, with $46,000,000 authorized for fiscal year 1994 and additional funding for subsequent years. The Food, Drug and Cosmetic Act is amended to include a new section for tuberculosis drug and device research. The Commissioner of Food and Drugs will implement a program to assist in developing tuberculosis protocols, review medical devices for tuberculosis diagnosis, and conduct research on drugs and devices for tuberculosis prevention. $5,000,000 is authorized for each fiscal year for this program.
